clinical_study.brief_title: Self-Management for Amputee Rehabilitation Using Technology
clinical_study.official_title: Self-Management for Amputee Rehabilitation Using Technology (SMART) Phase 2

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine the effect of 14 weeks of the SMART Program on the walking capacity and confidence of individuals with unilateral lower limb amputation (LLA). Our primary hypothesis is that SMART can improve walking capacity in individuals with LLA. Our secondary hypothesis is that SMART can improve ambulation confidence, knowledge, and skills for self-management, depression, body image, pain, balance confidence, dynamic balance, activities of daily living, satisfaction with life and habit formation for walking in individuals with LLA.

detailed_description.textblock:
Participants will receive a tablet preloaded with a dedicated icon that enables direct connection to the SMART platform. In-person training on tablet use and the online SMART platform will be provided for participants. A 'quick startup' guide will be affixed to the back of the tablet. Participants will be asked to complete one education module per week at their own convenience over the 10-week intervention period. The educational modules include psychological adaptation, residual limb management, nutrition/weight control, managing a prosthetic limb, managing chronic conditions and enhancing mobility. The modules include instructional movies, goal setting logs, and quizzes. A module can be stopped or "re-wound" at any point, and the participant's place and work-to-date is automatically saved. The SMART platform will be asynchronously monitored through a web portal by the trainer, who will be a PhD candidate in Rehabilitation Sciences and observe participant progress and provide feedback if required. If there is no online activity within a 7-day (consecutive) period, the trainer will contact the participant to inquire the reasons for inactivity and troubleshoot any problems including technical issues.
Clinical outcomes measures will be collected at three timepoints (T1-T3).

primary_outcome.description: functional assessment of walking capacity measured in meters over 2min

secondary_outcome.description: 22-item questionnaire where participants are asked to rate questions on a scale from 0 (not confident at all) to 10( extremely confident)
13 item measure that assesses patient knowledge, skill and confidence for self-management with ratings from 1 (strongly disagree) to 4 (strongly agree) and 'not applicable' as an additional option

secondary_outcome.measure: The Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D)
secondary_outcome.description: self-rating measure assessing depression, with final scores ranging from 0 to 60, with total score above 23 indicating clinical depression

other_outcome.description: 14-item measure that evaluates self perception of body image in individuals with LLA, exploring their feelings about physical appearance, levels of anxiety and comfort in various social situations after amputation

A questionnaire will be used to assess both pain frequency and intensity over one week in three categories: residual limb pain (pain in the above portion of the amputated site), phantom limb pain (pain in the missing portion of the limb), and the nonpainful phantom limb sensation (sensations in the missing portion of the limb which were not painful)
16-item self-report measure that assesses perceived balance confidence, which is important for mobility
timed measure for dynamic standing balance
10-item scale that measures independence in self-care and mobility
5-item measure scored on a Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).
12-item questionnaire based on the 7-point Likert scale with the range of total score between 0 to 84, which higher scores show the stronger habit strength

clinical_study.condition: Unilateral Trans Tibial/Femoral Lower Limb Amputation

intervention.intervention_name: Self-Management for Amputee Rehabilitation using Technology [SMART]
intervention.description: Participants will complete a 10-week tablet-based education program for individuals with LLA that will provide them with self-management education.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- adults who are older than 50 years of age, as this age range includes over half of individuals with LLAs (Imam, et al., 2017).
- individuals who are post trans-tibial/trans-femoral amputation within the past 10 years and using a definitive socket-based prosthetic limb for at least a year on a daily basis
- English speaking
- live in Lower Mainland of Vancouver within 50km of GF Strong Rehabilitation Centre.
- They must also have functional use of at least one hand in order to use the tablet.
Exclusion Criteria:
- people who are unable to use a tablet for the duration of the intervention due to visual or auditory impairment, or who have cognitive impairments or decline.
